name: 歐美近代史學思潮研討
goals: Ability to identify problems and initiate enquiry
Ability to read classic historiography works in English
Ability to write research papers in English
syllabus:
There are two textbooks for this course:

 1. Sarah Maza, _Thinking About History_ (University of Chicago Press, 2017)

Chinese Translation Available: 莎拉．瑪扎（Sarah Maza）著，陳建元譯，《想想歷史》（台北：時報文化，2018）。

2\. Jeremy Popkin, _From Herodotus to H-Net: The Story of Historiography_ (Oxford University Press, 2015, 2019)  

**Two to three students will present each week. Each student will spend 25-30 minutes discussing and presenting his or her topic,  followed by time for the teacher to answer questions and lead a discussion.**

\=========================================================================

**Week 1  (2022/9/5)** 

Introduction and assignment of students for each week's discussion

**Week 2 (9/12) (**Maza, 2017)  **pp. 10-28** 

History from Above: “Great Men” and a Few Women

Social History and Quantification

E. P. Thompson’s Historical Revolution

**Week 3 (9/19) (**Maza, 2017)  **pp. 28-57**

Resistance and Agency

Power and the Private Sphere

How National History Became Unnatural

**Week 4 (9/26) (**Maza, 2017)  **pp. 57-82**

Oceans, Middle Grounds, Borderlands

The Rise of Global History

Displacing Euro-America

**Week 5 (10/3)  (**Maza, 2017)  **pp. 83-96**

From Ideas to Things

The Changing History of Ideas

Thomas Kuhn’s Scientific Revolution

**Week 6 10/10   National Day (Holiday)**

**Week 7   (10/17)  (**Maza, 2017)  **pp. 96-117** 

Science in Historical Context

The New History of Things

Nature and Other Nonhuman Actors

**Week 8  Mid-Term Break** (1024) 

**Week 9. (10/31) (**Maza, 2017)  **pp. 118-146**

From Chroniclers to Academics

Popular and Public History

Orthodoxy and Revisionism: How Debate Shapes History

**Week 10  (11/7 )**

Do Sources and Archives Make History?

Causality and History

In Search of Laws and Patterns: Social Science History and Comparison

**Week 11 (11/14)  Guest Lecture**

**Week 12 (11/21)** 

Marxism and the Annales School

Multicausal History and the Return of the Event

In Search of Meaning: Microhistory

**Week 13 (11/28)** 

Clifford Geertz, Michel Foucault, and the “New Cultural History”

The Rise and Fall of Objectivity

Postmodernism and History: Radical Skepticism and New Methods

**Week 14 (12/5).**

Everything Is Constructed

Barbarians at the Gate

Distortion or Imagination: Where Do We Draw the Line?

**Week 15 (12/12)   Jeremy D. Poplin’s monograph**

The Challenges of the 1960s

Searching for a New History

New Paradigms for History

**Week 16    (12/19)**

Final Exam Week

methodologies.note: According to the weekly theme, students will report their reading experience and opinions, and then discuss with teachers and students.

grading.note: Presentation / group presentation, and involvement in class discussion.
